senses.title: Super Senses
senses.subtitle: Extraordinary abilities that go far beyond human perception
senses.intro: Many animals perceive the world in ways humans can barely imagine. Explore these extraordinary sensory abilities.
senses.echolocation.how: Bats and dolphins emit high-frequency sound pulses and listen for echoes bouncing off objects. By analyzing the time delay, intensity, and frequency shift of returning echoes, they create a detailed 3D map of their surroundings — even in complete darkness.
senses.infrared.how: Pit vipers like rattlesnakes have specialized pit organs between their eyes and nostrils that detect infrared radiation (heat). These organs contain a membrane with thousands of heat-sensitive receptors, allowing them to 'see' the body heat of warm-blooded prey even in total darkness.
senses.magnetic.how: Animals like sea turtles and migratory birds have magnetite crystals or specialized proteins (cryptochromes) in their bodies that detect Earth's magnetic field. This built-in compass allows them to navigate thousands of kilometers during migration with remarkable precision.
senses.electroreception.how: Sharks and rays have hundreds of jelly-filled pores called ampullae of Lorenzini that detect the tiny electrical fields generated by the muscle contractions and heartbeats of other animals. This allows them to locate hidden prey buried in sand or murky water.
senses.ultrasound.how: Some animals can produce and detect sound frequencies far above the human hearing range (above 20 kHz). Bats use ultrasound up to 200 kHz for echolocation, while dolphins can hear up to 150 kHz, enabling precise detection of objects and communication.
senses.polarized.how: Many insects and cephalopods have specialized photoreceptors that can detect the polarization pattern of light. Bees use polarized light from the sky as a compass for navigation, while octopuses and mantis shrimp use it to detect transparent prey and communicate.
senses.pressure.how: Fish have a lateral line system — a series of fluid-filled canals with hair cells along their bodies that detect changes in water pressure and vibrations. Sharks and crocodiles have similar systems that sense the slightest water movements from nearby prey or predators.
senses.chemical.how: Many animals have extraordinary chemical detection abilities far beyond human taste and smell. Dogs have up to 300 million olfactory receptors (vs. 6 million in humans), snakes taste the air with their forked tongues, and ants communicate complex messages through pheromone trails.

records.title: Records & Extremes
records.subtitle: The most extraordinary achievements in the animal kingdom
records.intro: Nature's record holders push the limits of what biology can achieve. Discover the most extreme animals on Earth.
records.fastest_land.desc: The cheetah is the undisputed speed champion on land, reaching 120 km/h in short bursts covering distances up to 500 m. It can accelerate from 0 to 100 km/h in just 3 seconds.
records.fastest_bird.desc: The peregrine falcon is the fastest animal on Earth, reaching speeds of 389 km/h during its hunting dive (stoop). In level flight, it cruises at around 65-90 km/h.
records.largest_animal.desc: The blue whale is the largest animal ever known to have lived on Earth, weighing up to 150,000 kg and measuring up to 30 meters long. Its heart alone is the size of a small car.
records.tallest_animal.desc: The giraffe stands up to 5.5 meters tall, with its neck alone measuring about 1.8 meters. Despite its length, a giraffe's neck has only 7 vertebrae — the same as humans.
records.longest_lived.desc: Sea turtles can live well over 100 years. The oldest known tortoise, Jonathan, is over 190 years old. Their slow metabolism and protective shells contribute to their extraordinary longevity.
records.strongest_bite.desc: The saltwater crocodile has the most powerful bite ever measured at 3,700 PSI — strong enough to crush bones and turtle shells. For comparison, a human bite is about 162 PSI.
records.deepest_diver.desc: Humpback whales can dive to depths of around 500 meters. The Cuvier's beaked whale holds the absolute record at nearly 3,000 meters — deeper than many submarines can go.
records.highest_flyer.desc: Golden eagles soar at altitudes of up to 3,600 meters. The Rüppell's vulture holds the absolute record at 11,300 meters — high enough to encounter commercial aircraft.
records.best_eyesight.desc: Bald eagles have vision roughly 8 times sharper than humans. They can spot a rabbit from over 3 km away. Their eyes have two foveas, allowing both telescopic and wide-angle vision simultaneously.
records.best_smell.desc: Dogs have up to 300 million olfactory receptors compared to about 6 million in humans, making their sense of smell roughly 100,000 times more sensitive. They can detect some odors in parts per trillion.
records.most_venomous.desc: The box jellyfish (Chironex fleckeri) is considered the most venomous marine animal. Its tentacles contain millions of nematocysts that inject toxin capable of killing a human in minutes.
records.most_intelligent.desc: Chimpanzees are our closest relatives, sharing about 98.7% of our DNA. They use tools, have complex social structures, can learn sign language, and demonstrate self-awareness, planning, and empathy.

conservation_overview.subtitle: How animals are doing worldwide
wisdom.p1: Every creature on Earth has evolved over millions of years to fill a unique niche. From the cheetah's explosive speed to the bat's ultrasonic sonar, nature has crafted solutions that human engineers still struggle to replicate.
wisdom.p2: The animal kingdom is a web of interconnected relationships — predators and prey, pollinators and plants, parasites and hosts. Understanding these bonds helps us protect the biodiversity that sustains all life, including our own.
wisdom.p3: Explore the fascinating world of animals and discover why every species matters.

privacy.title: Privacy Policy
privacy.intro: Your privacy matters to us. This page explains how Wildpedia handles your data.
privacy.what.title: What Data We Collect
privacy.what.text: Wildpedia stores your language preference and quiz scores locally in your browser using localStorage. No personal data is collected, transmitted, or stored on any server.
privacy.cookies.title: Cookies
privacy.cookies.text: Wildpedia does not use cookies. All preferences are stored in your browser's localStorage, which you can clear at any time through your browser settings.
privacy.analytics.title: Analytics
privacy.analytics.text: Wildpedia does not use any analytics or tracking services. No data about your visits, behavior, or device is collected or shared with third parties.
privacy.rights.title: Your Rights
privacy.rights.text: Since we do not collect any personal data, there is no personal information to access, modify, or delete. You can clear all locally stored preferences by clearing your browser's localStorage.
privacy.contact.title: Contact
privacy.contact.text: If you have any questions about this privacy policy, please open an issue on our GitHub repository.
about.title: About Wildpedia
about.intro: Wildpedia is a free platform helping people discover and appreciate the animal kingdom.
about.mission.title: Our Mission
about.mission.text: Our mission is to make animal knowledge accessible, engaging, and visually compelling. We believe that understanding animals is the first step toward protecting them and the ecosystems they inhabit.
about.data.title: Our Data
about.data.text: All animal data is carefully curated from peer-reviewed scientific sources, wildlife databases, and conservation organizations. We regularly update our database to ensure accuracy and completeness.
about.open.title: Free & Open
about.open.text: Wildpedia is free to use, ad-free, and publicly available on GitHub. All data comes from trusted public sources. We welcome feedback from developers, biologists, educators, and animal enthusiasts.
about.features.title: Features
about.features.text: Wildpedia includes detailed animal profiles, side-by-side comparisons, an interactive world map, knowledge quizzes, and six thematic exploration categories.
about.audience.title: Who Is This For?
about.audience.text: Students, teachers, wildlife enthusiasts, and anyone curious about the natural world. Wildpedia is designed for all ages and knowledge levels.
about.tech.title: Technology
about.tech.text: Built with vanilla HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. No frameworks, no server needed. Just open it in your browser.
methodology.title: Data Sources & Methodology
methodology.intro: Wildpedia strives for scientific accuracy. Below are the key sources we reference for our animal data.
methodology.sources.title: Primary Sources
methodology.sources.iucn: IUCN Red List of Threatened Species — Conservation status, population trends, and threat assessments.
methodology.sources.adw: Animal Diversity Web (University of Michigan) — Comprehensive taxonomy, habitat, and behavior data.
methodology.sources.natgeo: National Geographic — Wildlife profiles, habitat information, and conservation stories.
methodology.sources.wwf: World Wildlife Fund (WWF) — Conservation data, species profiles, and threat analysis.
methodology.sources.arkive: Wildscreen Arkive — Species descriptions and natural history.
methodology.sources.eol: Encyclopedia of Life — Species-level data, distribution maps, and ecological information.
methodology.sources.smithsonian: Smithsonian National Zoo — Animal behavior, physiology, and captive breeding data.
methodology.sources.wikipedia: Wikipedia — Cross-referenced for general facts and supplementary details.
methodology.accuracy.title: Accuracy & Updates
methodology.accuracy.text: We cross-reference multiple sources for each data point. Animal data is reviewed periodically and updated as new scientific findings emerge.
methodology.contribute.title: Contribute
methodology.contribute.text: If you spot an error or want to suggest an update, please open an issue on our GitHub repository.
methodology.citation.title: How to Cite
